intro: Silene saxifraga subsp. smithii, commonly known as the Smith's catchfly, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its slender stems and small, white to pinkish flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly habitats, often in alpine or subalpine regions. Its leaves are linear to lanceolate, and it produces capsules as its fruiting structure. Silene saxifraga subsp. smithii is adapted to harsh environments and is often found in open, sunny areas with well-drained soil.
